content:
Certainly! Here is the solution with the superscripts and a vinculum instead of "\frac":

Differentiate the function f(x) = (x² - 4x + 3) / (x - 1).

First, let's differentiate the numerator using the power rule:

g'(x) = 2x¹ - 4

Next, let's differentiate the denominator using the power rule:

h'(x) = 1

Now, we can use the quotient rule to find the derivative of the entire function:

f'(x) =

⎛g'(x)h(x) - g(x)h'(x)⎞
⎜────────────────────⎟
⎝ h(x)² ⎠

=

⎛(2x¹ - 4)(x¹ - 1) - (x² - 4x¹ + 3)(1)⎞
⎜────────────────────────────────────⎟
⎝ (x¹ - 1)² ⎠

=

⎛2x² - 4x¹ - x² + 4x¹ - 3⎞
⎜──────────────────────⎟
⎝ (x¹ - 1)² ⎠

=

⎛-x² + 8x¹ - 3⎞
⎜────────────⎟
⎝ (x¹ - 1)² ⎠

And that's it! You have successfully differentiated the function using the quotient rule.

I hope this helps. Let me know if you have any other questions.
